Patagonia keeps close tabs on wages paid in all of the factories making our goods to ensure the workers are earning at least a minimum wage in the regions where they work.
However, even a minimum wage, which is set by local government, is often not high enough to allow for the basic necessities in life.
As a result, Patagonia has made the commitment to confirming that living wages are paid to all workers making our apparel by 2025.

A living wage is one that allows someone to afford decent food, water, housing, health care, education, clothing, transportation, child care and other essential needs, including savings for unexpected events.
This is not an easy task: not every country has a reliable living-wage estimate available, and there aren’t set examples mapping out how to get to living wages over time.
